Week 29 Appendix: Law, Maps, and Memory as Control

In a week of consolidation rather than shock, law, representation, and information were tightened to favor power while formal democratic shells stayed intact.

This was an exceptionally heavy week of structural pressure toward authoritarianism, with coordinated moves across executive power, immigration enforcement, higher education, and information control. The administration deepened its campaign to politicize neutral state functions: firing the labor statistics chief, purging FBI leadership, and weaponizing DOJ against Jack Smith and New York AG Letitia James all push traits 4, 14, 19, 22, and 51. Simultaneously, immigration and detention policy hardened dramatically—expanding ICE capacity at Fort Bliss and Indiana, entrenching ‘Alligator Alcatraz’, and conducting raids in defiance of court orders—driving traits 4, 9, 11, 46, and 47. Universities were coerced into ideological settlements and data mandates, while Harvard sued to resist, sharply affecting trait 44 and related memory traits. Aggressive mid‑decade gerrymanders in Texas and planned redistricting in Indiana, backed by threats of arrest and FBI involvement, intensified structural manipulation of representation (traits 6, 11, 15, 45). Finally, sweeping tariffs, a homelessness‑criminalization order, and cuts to food assistance and mRNA research combined economic and social policy to entrench inequality and weaken evidence‑based governance (traits 16, 26, 36, 39, 53).
